question_text: Human computer interaction is...

choices.option_text: A discipline concerned with the design and audit of personal computers for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them.
A discipline concerned with the testing and audit of interactive computing systems for human use and with the study of events surrounding them.
A discipline concerned with the design, evaluation and implementation of interactive systems for human use and with the study of major phenomena surrounding them.
A discipline concerned with the design and implementation of machines for human use and with the study of phenomena surrounding them.

question_text:
Which of the following is NOT an interactive system?

1. Spork
2. Social media websites
3. Mobile applications
4. Game controllers

choices.option_text: 1 and 4 only.
2, 3 and 4 only.
4 only.
1 only.

question_text: Poorly designed interfaces can...

choices.option_text: incur additional costs
improve health
improve morale
decrease productivity

question_text: User experience is:

choices.option_text: a person's perceptions and responses that result from the use of a product, system or service.
the extent to which a product can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction.
the measurement of many people's feelings towards a product.
the perceivable action possibilities that an a person understands from an object..

question_text: Which of the following is a usability goal?

choices.option_text: Fun
Effectiveness
Boring
Utility

question_text: Which of the following design principles support learnability?

choices.option_text: Consistency
Conviviality
Affordances
Visibility

question_text: All design rules must be followed in practice.
explanation:
Ideally, yes, but some rules will contradict the other. 

This must be considered before you adopt a specific rule.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Which of the following is an example of a design standard?

choices.option_text: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)
Visibility
Schneiderman Eight Golden Rules

question_text: Match Schneiderman's Eight Golden Rules that are similar to Nielsen 10 Usability Heuristics.
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
    - Design dialogue to yield closure.

matching_pairs.left_item: Enable frequent users to use shortcuts.

question_text: Counters and progress bars used to indicate how much of an operation is complete is an example of  ____________.

choices.option_text: Visibility
Affordances
Feedback
Consistency

question_text: _________ is an interaction pattern aim at duping users to getting them to do things that they did not intend to do.

choices.option_text: Dark Pattern
Design Pattern
Anti-pattern
Software Pattern

question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

choices.option_text: It is possible to make ALL interfaces consistent through the use of design standards.
There is a secret formula that you can use to design good interfaces.
The graying out of buttons to prevent users from proceeding is an example of constraints.
All design principles must be demonstrated by a single product.

question_text: Which of the following is an example of a cognitive process?

choices.option_text: Perception
Problem-solving
Listening
Attention

question_text: Which Gestalt Laws of perception help to resolve ambiguity and fill in missing data?

choices.option_text: Proximity
Figure/Ground
Continuity
Similarity

question_text: What is Norman's Gulf of execution?

choices.option_text: One of the first HCI models to be derived from the information processing theory
The amount of effort required to determine the system state
Distance between the user's goals and the means of achieving them through the system

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE?

choices.option_text: Our short term memory is limited.
Our memory is perfect.
Humans are good at multi-tasking.
Our attention is limited.

question_text: Which of the following Gestalt Laws of Perception can be used to direct attention?

choices.option_text: Similarity
Figure and Ground
Proximity
Common Fate

question_text: Creating a gap between two distinct groups of objects is...

choices.option_text: an example of continuity.
an example of similarity.
an example of common fate.
an example of proximity.

question_text: Match the following explanation to each term.
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
- Memories that last forever
- Memories related to sound in caves.
- A person or building that we perceive positively.

matching_pairs.right_item: Sensory buffer for our auditory perception
Stores knowledge on how to do things

matching_definitions.right_item: Memories related to sound in caves.
A person or building that we perceive positively.
Stores knowledge on how to do things
Sensory buffer for our auditory perception

question_text: Match examples of needs and motivation to the correct term.
Which of the following are examples of affective computing?

choices.option_text: Technology that replaces manual labour in the construction site.
Systems that recognizes human emotions through speech and visual images.
An android with facial expression.

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE about human capabilities and limitations?

choices.option_text: Recognition is easy; recall is even easier.
You are reading this text using your peripheral vision.
Our vision is optimized to see structure.
Our hand-eye coordination follows laws. An example is Hicks Law which dictates reaction time is dependent on the number of options available.

question_text: All users are stakeholders.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Which of the following are principles of user-centered design? (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: Understanding who the users will be by studying their cognitive, behavioral and attitudinal characteristics.
Observing, measuring and analyzing the reactions and performance of intended users to prototypes.
When problems are found; don't fix these until official complaints are filed when the product is released.

question_text: Why must the problem space be explored and articulated at the start of the project? (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: To understand the context for which it will be used.
To reduce misunderstanding between team members.
Marks are awarded for it during the project.
To determine the purpose of design.
To determine possible current user expectations.

question_text: It is important to involve users throughout the design and development process because: (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: we can get feedback from the users perspective.
we can demand and receive more resources from management for development.
they can see the product's capabilities from an early stage.
users who are involved will feel a sense of ownership towards it and support its use.

question_text: Which of the following are basic activities of interaction design? (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: Prototyping the alternative designs so that they can be communicated and assessed.
Evaluating the product and the user experience that it offers throughout the process.
Designing alternatives that meet the requirements.
Discovering requirements for the interactive product.

question_text: The lifecycle model (or process model) is used to... (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: represent a model that captures a set of activities and how they are related.
showcase your artistic skill in using digital tools.
tell each team what they must do and the sequence that it must be done.
force everyone to follow the same activities during the project.

question_text: We must follow AgileUX process during the project.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Select ALL the statements that are TRUE.

choices.option_text: User-centered design helps designer move away from their preferences and focus on the users' needs and goals.
Users sometimes don't know what they want.
User-centered design can result in the development of a wrong product if the wrong set or type of users are chosen.
You need to be a genius in order to use the Genius Design approach.

question_text: PACT analysis must always be done to scope out a design problem.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: The PACT framework helps designers: (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: to determine the requirements of the system, services or product without direct users involvement.
to understand the activities that people want to undertake and the contexts in which those activities take place.
to know about the features of interactive technologies and how to approach designing interactive systems and services that deliver a good UX.
understand the people who will use their systems, services and products.

question_text: The lifecycle model is created at the start of the project and followed strictly during the project.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Select all the statements that are TRUE about PACT framework. (select all that apply)

choices.option_text: P in PACT refers to all the contents covered in human information processing model.
The type of input technology required by the system is dependent on the type of data and instructions to be provided by the user.
Printers are a form of output technology as it allows users to produce physical copies of the contents.
Designers must also factor in the cost of the user's internet package for T in PACT when considering bandwidth and speed.
Context can be analyzed independent of activity.

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE?

choices.option_text: Users cannot articulate what they want so it is pointless to ask them for their opinion.
Sales and marketing is responsible for setting the requirements.
We can forgo doing user research because our team has no time to perform such studies.
We may not be the end users of the product we design.

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE?

choices.option_text: The 'could haves' in Moscow rule are the next important requirements after 'must haves'.
The 'would have' is of the utmost priority.
The 'must have' is of the utmost priority.
The 'would haves' in Moscow rule is what the team should deliver once they are complete with the other requirements.

question_text: Which of the following statements about 'Interviews' are correct?

choices.option_text: During the interview, the interviewer should be polite and carefully steer the conversation.
Non-verbal communications should be avoided as it may confuse the note-taker.
Part of the preparation of the note-taker is to understand the interview guide and know the important terms of the domain.
The interviewer should prepare all questions to be asked in the interview upfront.

question_text: Which of the following statements are wrong about 'Observations'?

choices.option_text: It is important to know the distinction between open-ended and close-ended questions.
Observing two people at work is called think aloud.
The observer has no bias.
Beware of the note-taker's observation bias.

question_text: Which of the following statements about 'Surveys' are correct?

choices.option_text: In non-probabilistic sampling, it is important to collect demographic data about the respondents.
It provides deep and rich data about the participants.
It can be self-administer and done remotely.
It must be deployed using a survey tool.

question_text: Which of the following is an example of close-ended ordered response?

choices.option_text: Binary response
Likert scale
Rank order
Multiple choice selections

question_text: You have made an appointment to interview a dietitian to learn more about healthy eating and diet recommendations for diabetic patients. Which of the following are appropriate data recording approaches that can be used during the session?

choices.option_text: Audio recording
Diaries
Key-stroke logging
Eye-tracking

question_text: These are the requirements that you have noted down for the healthy eating and diet recommendations application targeted for diabetic patients. Match the requirements.
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
- Usability requirements

matching_pairs.left_item: The application must calculate the total amount of calories consumed by the patient at each meal.
Images of the user's current meal must be stored with its timestamp to track the user's last meal.
Users will always eat their meals at venues with sufficient lighting to view their food.
Permission of use must be given by the legal guardian for users below the age of 11.
The application must make the users feel guilty when their current meal is unbalance.

question_text: Which of the following should NOT be done when you are planning a data gathering session?

choices.option_text: Prepare documents to inform participants of their rights and how data will be collected during the session.
Identify the purpose of the data gathering session.
Perform pilot studies to validate results after the actual session.
Run pilot studies to test the tools and procedures before the actual session.

question_text:
An obstetrician have requested the development of a mobile application for expectant mothers with pregnancy complications to keep track of their's and their child's health status during pregnancy. He has a requested that the application has a report function that allows his patients to send him a consolidated report before their check-up session. He has given samples of the type of reports and information that he expects from his clients.

To elicit requirements for the mobile application, you have shadowed (with permission) the obstetrician for a day. Which of the following statements is most likely correct?

choices.option_text: The approach makes sense because you can understand what the obstetrician does during a check-up.
The approach makes sense because the obstetrician will be using the information that is reported by the mobile application.
The approach makes no sense because shadowing is not a requirements elicitation technique.
The approach makes no sense because the end users of the mobile application is not the obstetrician.

question_text:
An obstetrician have requested the development of a mobile application for expectant mothers with pregnancy complications to keep track of their's and their child's health status during pregnancy. He has a requested that the application has a report function that allows his patients to send him a consolidated report before their check-up session. He has given samples of the type of reports and information that he expects from his clients.

Which of the following describes the functional requirement of the application?

choices.option_text: The application should allow users to record the number of fetal movement felt in an hour at a specified time and day.
The user will be female between the ages of 16 to 50 and has experience using mobile applications.
The application will be used at the obstetrician office.
The application must be executable on Android 5 and above.

question_text: Which two aspects are the most important to take into consideration in the choice of data gathering technique to elicit requirements for a new e-learning platform?

choices.option_text: Tools available
Age of the stakeholders
Project deadlines and budget
Availability of stakeholders

question_text: What are the two key advantages of using questionnaires for requirements gathering?

choices.option_text: Questionnaires allow participants to be anonymous.
A high number of participants is possible.
Statistically relevant statements on requirements can be made.
Questionnaires allow the participants' understanding to be validated.

question_text: Contextual inquiry is a combination of:

choices.option_text: Interview
Survey
Observation
Studying documentation

question_text: Which of the following is an example of qualitative data?

choices.option_text: Recording of a user
Age
Likert scale responses
Binary responses

question_text: The following describes the steps to prepare data for statistical analysis. Identify example activities that are performed for each step.
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
- Interviewing the respondents again to clarify their response
- Convert open responses into numeric values

matching_pairs.right_item: Convert closed responses into numeric values

matching_definitions.right_item: Interviewing the respondents again to clarify their response
Convert open responses into numeric values
Convert closed responses into numeric values

question_text: We must always use SPSS software to analyze quantitative data.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Which of the following features can be used to describe a data?

choices.option_text: Mode
Standard deviation
Mean
One-way ANOVA

question_text: Match the syntax to the meaning.
What do actors mean in a use-case diagram?

choices.option_text: Internal system
Person
User
Function

question_text: Which of the following contents should be included in a persona?

choices.option_text: Skill set
Sequence of Events
Identity
Setting

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE?

choices.option_text: It is ok to pre-empt an answer when asking questions during the interview
Interviews can be used almost in any stage of the project
Unstructured interviews have a set of defined questions

question_text: The figure below shows a HTA for the task of 'Joining a group on Canvas'. Which of the following statements are TRUE?

choices.option_text: "Join a group on Canvas" should be set as Task 0.
To perform sub-task 1, plan 1 should be do 1.1 then 1.2
We should remove all the horizontal lines below the boxes.
Sub-task "Scroll to Group of choice" and "Click 'Join' "should be set to Task 3 and Task 4 respectively.

question_text: User stories in scenario-based design approach are created from the imagination of team members.

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Which of the following is TRUE about the affinity diagram?

choices.option_text: Can be used to organize language data into themes.
We must crowd around a whiteboard to create an affinity diagram.
Put all data into one post-it note to save the trees.
We cannot discard any of the cards during sorting.

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about personas?

choices.option_text: Can be used to inform design decisions
They are created from data collected from actual people.
Can be used to replace real users during testing.
They are real living people.

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE?

choices.option_text: Prototyping is all about making compromises.
We must always use a prototyping tool to create prototypes.
Sketching is quick way to communicate ideas.
Aesthetics should be prioritised during prototyping.

question_text: Select ALL statements about mental models that are TRUE.

choices.option_text: The designer's mental model is called conceptual model.
If the user's mental model of the system is correct, the user will know how to use the system.
Systems cannot be built without a clear mental model upfront..
All users will have the same mental model when they look at the system.

question_text: Which of the following is TRUE about interface metaphors?

choices.option_text: We must always use interface metaphors in our design.
'Surfing the web' is a metaphor to conceptualize what we do on the web.
Metaphors must be carefully designed to avoid confusion.

question_text: Interaction types are the ways a person interacts with a product. Match each interaction type with respect to the user's action with the system.

matching_pairs.right_item: User receives information from the system and chooses whether to respond.
User tells system what to do.
Users have a dialog with a system.
Users move through a virtual environment or a physical space.
Users interact with objects in a virtual or physical space.

matching_definitions.right_item: Users interact with objects in a virtual or physical space.
User receives information from the system and chooses whether to respond.
User tells system what to do.
Users have a dialog with a system.
Users move through a virtual environment or a physical space.

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE about interface types and interaction types.

choices.option_text: New interface types will emerge and existing interface types may become obsolete.
We must always use menus and buttons for instructing.
They are both referring to the same thing.
Both concepts are closely related but different.

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about selecting appropriate interface types for an application?

choices.option_text: It is affected by the application's requirements.
You must stick with what you know will work.
It depends on the environment of use.
It must be determined by the users.

question_text: Select the most appropriate envisionment technique that you can use in the following situations:
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
- Balsamiq
- Figma
- Persona

matching_pairs.left_item: Describe the user actions in using the envisioned product and its surrounding context.
User's view of the screen when he launches the application for the first time.
A tangible representation that the participant can use during a usability test session.

question_text: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

choices.option_text: You must use high grade writing utensils to create sketches.
You need to spend a few days sketching to increase the chances of your colleagues listening to your ideas.
Sketching is a good communication tool during brainstorming.

question_text: Which of the following statements best describes the Wizard of Oz technique?

choices.option_text: It is most useful to convince investors that the system is working and ready for production.
The user is under the impression that he is interacting with the actual system but the outputs seen by the user is generated by another person.
Wizard is the name of the prototype.
The person who invented the technique lived in Oz.

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about video prototypes?

choices.option_text: You must have experience in photography and cinematography to create them.
Demonstrates dynamically and visually what the interaction looks like.
It is interactive.
It can be used to bring wireframe sketches to life.

question_text: Which of the following are examples of low fidelity prototypes?

choices.option_text: Functional prototype created in Figma
Sketches
Paper prototypes

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about Wireframes?

choices.option_text: Outlines structure and layout of the page
View of a single screen or interaction page
Must be provided by the client.
Sequence of actions or events the user and the product go through to achieve goal

question_text: Select all evaluation techniques that requires users involvement.

choices.option_text: Lab studies
Heuristic Evaluation
Fitts Law
In-the-wild studies

question_text: Name the method that does not need user involvement for evaluation

choices.option_text: Cognitive Walkthrough
In-the-wild studies
Lab studies

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about heuristic evaluation?

choices.option_text: Involves expert users
It can be used at early stages of design.
You only need to note down principles that are violated.
It can be conducted alone.

question_text: What can we evaluate in HCI?

choices.option_text: Weather conditions
Early and subsequent prototypes of the system
Conceptual model
Final product

question_text: What are the benefits of running studies in naturalistic settings?

choices.option_text: Situation and behaviour are more natural
Easy to arrange and run
Less time consuming compared to lab studies
Easy to control

question_text: Which of the following factors must be considered when you are determining the total number of participants required for a usability test?

choices.option_text: Budget
Test until there are no new insights
Test as many people as we can
Time

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about usability tests?

choices.option_text: The participant is given tasks to complete using the prototype.
We must always collect eye movement data, audio and visuals during the test.
Usability tests represent a natural situation
The participant should be allowed to stop when he wants to.

question_text: It's good to have a combination of with and without participants methods when running evaluations

choices.option_text: True
False

question_text: Which of the following documents must you provide to the participant before a usability test?

choices.option_text: Post-questionnaire if any
Participant Information Statement
Pre-questionnaire if any
Participant Consent Form

question_text: Select all types of quantitative data that can be measured during the a usability test session.

choices.option_text: Number of errors made per task.
Number of navigations to the online help or manuals.
Critical incidents that happen during the test.
Time taken to complete task.

question_text: Match example evaluation methods to their categories.
explanation:
Other Incorrect Match Options:
- Cognitive walkthrough

matching_pairs.left_item: Evaluation with users under controlled settings
Compared with a set of known design rules

question_text: Which of the following methods are user studies?

choices.option_text: Field Studies
Usability Testing
Fitts Law
Cognitive Walkthrough

question_text: You suspect that context menus will be easier for user's to make selection as opposed to cascading menus. You are planning an experiment to prove this. Match each term to correct statement:

matching_pairs.right_item: Time taken to select an option
It is faster to select options from context menus than cascade menus.

matching_definitions.right_item: It is faster to select options from context menus than cascade menus.
Time taken to select an option

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about counterbalancing?

choices.option_text: All your participants must be able to do Latin square counterbalancing.
It is used by within-subjects design to reduce order effect.
It is used by between-subjects design to reduce order effect.

question_text: Identify suitable evaluation methods for each of the following situations:

matching_pairs.left_item: Create knowledge about a population of study.
Identify opportunities provided by new technology

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE about field studies?

choices.option_text: You give participants the flexibility to do what they like with the prototype.
It is not considered human research.
Field study and in-the-wild study are the same thing.
You will need to shadow your participant the whole day in order to record the data.

question_text: Match the following description to the correct experimental design setup:

matching_pairs.left_item: All participants are allocated to only one test condition.
All participants will be exposed to all test conditions.
Individual differences among participants is an issue.

question_text: Which of the following statements are FALSE about  usability testing?

choices.option_text: Must be replicable
Discover new knowledge
Need many participants
Conditions do not have to be strongly controlled.

question_text: Which of the following needs to be considered during experimental design?

choices.option_text: Supervisor's view of experiment
Allocation of participants to test conditions
Participant selection and recruitment

question_text: Which HCI evaluation method involves observing users as they interact with a system in a controlled environment?

choices.option_text: Observations
Interviews
Usability testing
Surveys

question_text: Which of the following is NOT a usability heuristic developed by Jakob Nielsen?

choices.option_text: Visibility of system status
Error prevention
System adaptability
Match between system and the real world

question_text: Which HCI evaluation technique involves an expert going through the prototype pretending to be a user of the system

choices.option_text: Card sorting
Eye tracking
Think Aloud
Cognitive walkthrough

question_text: What is the purpose of A/B testing in HCI evaluation?

choices.option_text: To gather demographic information about users
To assess the user's cognitive load
To conduct user interviews
To compare two different user interface designs

question_text: In HCI, what does the term "affordance" refer to?

choices.option_text: The visual cues that suggest how an object can be used
The time it takes for a user to complete a task
The ability of a user interface to adapt to different devices
The perceived value of a product

question_text: Which of the following is a benefit of using paper prototypes in HCI?

choices.option_text: They allow for realistic user interactions.
They are easy to create and modify.
They can be used for quantifying user performance.
They are fully functional and represent the final product.

question_text: In HCI, what is the purpose of usability testing with prototypes?

choices.option_text: To uncover usability issues and gather user feedback
To create a final product specification
To validate the prototype's visual design
To simulate real-world usage of the final product

question_text: Which prototyping technique involves creating a physical model or representation of a user interface using tangible materials like clay or foam?

choices.option_text: Digital prototyping
Paper prototyping
Physical prototyping
Storyboarding

question_text: "Help and documentation" is one of Nielsen's usability heuristics. What does it suggest?

choices.option_text: Hiding user assistance options to reduce clutter
Providing a dedicated customer support hotline
Offering context-sensitive help within the interface
Providing comprehensive user manuals for all software

question_text: "Recognition rather than recall" is one of Nielsen's usability heuristics. What does it mean?

choices.option_text: Users should rely on their memory instead of on-screen instructions
Users must remember all interface features without any cues
Recognition is not as important as recall in usability
Users should be able to recognise and use features rather than memorise them

question_text: Which of the following statements are TRUE about Command Line Interfaces (CLI)?

choices.option_text: It is usually typed into a command prompt.
It can provide better accessibility for the visually impaired as it can be used together with screen readers and speech recognition software.
There is usually a picture representation to explain what each line of command means.
It is an old-fashioned interface type that is no longer adopted by any applications.

question_text: Match the description to each term

matching_pairs.right_item: Intuitive, do not need any expertise, not the most efficient for batch tasks
Are used in smart watches, smart walls, and even in artistic installations
Computer simulated environment, where the sensory experience is artificially created
Are always on and come in various form factors

matching_definitions.right_item: Are always on and come in various form factors
Intuitive, do not need any expertise, not the most efficient for batch tasks
Computer simulated environment, where the sensory experience is artificially created
Are used in smart watches, smart walls, and even in artistic installations

question_text: Which of the following are TRUE about wearable computing?

choices.option_text: Wearable interfaces can take on many form factors other formats other than the watch such as accessories, clothes and skin tattoos.
The essence of wearable computing is to embed computers into anythig that we normally use to cover or accessorize our bodies.
The laptop is an example of wearable computing because you place it on your lap.

question_text: Match the description to each term.

matching_pairs.left_item: Users are completely immerse in a completely different world from the physical world.
User views an overlay of digital graphics over a video stream of the physical world.
Virtual objects are part of the real world in real-time.

question_text: Which of the following are aspects of Post WIMP interfaces?

choices.option_text: Naive maths
Social awareness and skills
Spatial awareness and skills
Naive physics

question_text: Why do we need to understand the mechanism of face-to-face conversations?

choices.option_text: To design communication tools to support remote conversations between people better.
It is part of the syllabus.
Improves my contribution in the Group Project.
It can be used to design the dialogues that take place between users and chatbots or voice assistants.

question_text: Select the description that explains the difference between each term.

matching_pairs.right_item: Sense of being in the same virtual place or environment with the team..
Sense of being present while being physically located at a different location.
Degree of awareness, feeling and reaction to other people who are virtually present in the online environment.

matching_definitions.right_item: Degree of awareness, feeling and reaction to other people who are virtually present in the online environment.
Sense of being present while being physically located at a different location.
Sense of being in the same virtual place or environment with the team..

question_text: The time/space groupware matrix classifies collaborative application into four categories. Match the descriptions to explain what each category means.
Which of the following statements are TRUE about speech interfaces?

choices.option_text: Speech interfaces use the exploring interaction style
Speech interfaces enable hands-free interaction
Speech interfaces use the conversing interaction style
Speech interfaces use the manipulating interaction style
